Notes: Negative indicator - Low ecological value, can be invasive and reduce diversity
High ecologcial value but can be detrimental if overdominant
Native to southern and central England, and only found on open rideside edges, only weakly associated with woodland
Not included in TSH lowlands, but this is probably the woodland community that it is most stronly associated with. Particularly ancient woodland? Added into both acidic and base-rich.

In the TSH as acidic lowland, however Stace's New Flora of the British Isles cites - typically occurring in woodland habitats with neutral to mildly alkaline soils, often on calcareous or base-rich substrates. It is described as a species favouring shady, base-rich woodland floors rather than acidic conditions. Also backed up in Rose (Wild flower key) and Rodwell - Plant communities- so included BL where it is often found
Follows TSH

It is an appropriate species in all the woodland communities except perhaps acidic upland (generally too nutrient-poor and acidic) even though not included in any of the TSH. However it is quite ephemeral to early spring after which it becomes undetectable. So ommitted on this basis.
Excluded as appropriate as not in TSH, and ruderal species indicative of disturbance.
Missed off previously. In TSH, distinctive not easily confused, but delicate, easily overlooked (seen at Glen Finglas in the open SB area), a good indicator of upland ancient woodland / wood pasture
Follows TSH
Only added to exclude even though it is listed in TSH for base-rich habiats it is ruderal and more commong in disturbed ridesides
Follows TSH
Not listed in TSH, but strongly associated with high quality undisturbed Caldedonian pinewoods, whilst flowers in the summer it has evergreen year-round leaves.
Only red currant is listed in TSH, but both black & downy are lised as Woodland Specialist by Kirby, and they are challeging to tell apart.
It is a woodland specialist, but could easily be confused with cultivated daffodils, and it is not in the TSH
Follows TSH
Follows TSH

Follows TSH. All BBF grouped as high level of expertise needed to ID to species. Sometimes associated with disturbance mwhere it can overdominate but included as fronds create shaded, humid microhabitats that support moisture-loving invertebrates and provides shelter for small invertebrates and amphibians. It indicates stable, long-established woodland habitats and good ecological condition.
Follows TSH except inclusion in acidic lowland where it is also commonly found
Not in TSH, but on the woodland specialist list (Kirby) - Possibly could combine with Soft shield fern and just absorb cross-over of habiat types and save the ID to species level.
Not in TSH, but on the woodland specialist list (Kirby) - Easy ID - Most appropriate on base-rich soils, and also found in wet woodland where well drained, but humid, and shady.
Only on the TSH for base-rich upland, but it is one of the few fern species that can legitimately occur across all woodland types, provided there is enough moisture and shade
Widespread and common. Not on the TSH wet woodland types.

Not in TSH. Indicator of old woodland continuity and natural woodland edges, typical of ancient, rocky and undisturbed woodlands. Species are often hard to separate in the field and have similar ecological roles so grouped under 'sp.'

Strongly associated with constantly damp, acidic, nutrient-poor conditions.Typically found in wet woodland (especially alder carr), wooded valley mires, stream edges, flushes, and wet heath–woodland transitions. Requires permanently moist soils, often peaty, and some shelter from strong sun and wind. 
Often present in ancient, undisturbed wet woodlands in the west and north, and sometimes in the New Forest, Cornwall and Devon.
Not in TSH, but on the woodland specialist list (Kirby) - Possibly could combine with Hard shield fern and just absorb cross-over of habiat types and save the ID to species level.
Not in TSH, but common in woodland, particulaly ride sides, quite distinctive and easy to ID. Native plant supporting a range of pollinators. Indicative of dynamism, not necessarily antiquity.
Follows TSH - Easy ID - Pioneer species in disturbed or regenerating woodland habitats.
Follows TSH - Easy ID - Prefers open woodland condition

Difficult to ID to genus and species for the general practitioner. Included in species list so that a DOMIN score can be given to indicate over dominance. Some grasses are native and valuable indicators, others are disturbance-tolerant and competitive, and many are ambiguous or low diagnostic value.
Follows TSH - Stongly associated with base-rich to neutral soils
Follows TSH - Keystone species of acidic heath-woodland mosaics, supporting a range of specialist invertebrates, especially moths, bees, and spiders

Follows TSH - Strongly associated with ancient, undisturbed woodland on moist, base-rich, or neutral soils, Indicator of good woodland ecological condition and continuity. Uncommon but ecologically valuable

Follows TSH - Found in a wide range of habitats, but especially frequent in woodlands, hedgebanks, rocky areas, and shady disturbed ground. Occurs in both lowland and upland, and from acidic to base-rich soils, but prefers base-rich.

In TSH  only on AU, AL and WL, but occurs widely tolerating a wide range of soils and a woodland specialist - Hugely ecologically important as nectar and berry source, and increases structural diversity.
Follows TSH - A woodland generalist (Kirby) but like honeysuckle has a very high wildlife value
Occur across all woodland types, but species-level identification is needed to evaluate ecological value

Include foliose lichens as a functional group in all woodland habitat types, many are strongly associated with woodland ecological continuity, they are widely distributed, and ecologically valuable, supporting high invertebrate diversity, including micro-moths, springtails, and spiders.

Include foliose lichens as a functional group in all woodland habitat types, sensitive indicators of long woodland continuity, support diverse invertebrate communities, especially moths, beetles, mites, and spiders
Rare, and confined to really only base-rich lowland, sometimes in BU. Not easily distinguishable from garden escapees / cultivated varieties
Could include as a functional group in WU and WL, but ruderal species are potentially not ecologically indicative and would not be appropriate
Strongly associated with ancient, humid, or lightly managed woodland, and Atlantic upland. One of the indicators in the RRA.
Follows TSH
Follows TSH - Can be found in base-rich woodlands but needs a wetland hydrology so restrict only to wet woodland
Follows TSH with addition og BL as often found here and has a widespread UK distibution - Good contribution ecologically
Follows TSH - Southern and central distribution
Not in TSH but strongly associated with ancient woodland and base-rich soils

In TSH only listed in WU and WL, but whilst it does favour damper soils, it doesn't tolerate waterlogging. It is associated with base-rich woodlands W8 in lowlands and W9 in the uplands, and is fairly widespread across the UK.

Difficult to ID to genus and species for the general practitioner. Included in species list so that a DOMIN score can be given to indicate over dominance. Some mosses are valuable indicators, others are disturbance-tolerant and competitive, and many are ambiguous or low diagnostic value.

It is in TSH lists for WU and WL, and although it is valaubale as a food plant it ishighly indicative of disturbance and eutophication. Excluded as a ecological indicator. Useful to capture it, and it's DOMIN though, especially as it is so recognisable and easy to see across a plot.
Follows TSH - Does occue in BU but locally and generally to the south of the range only.
Can be 'invasive' if over dominant, but a good for woodland structure. In the TSH in BL
Not in TSH - A really good indicator of ancient woodland but uncommon and ephemeral so excluded.
Not in TSH - But widespread across the UK, except in wet woodlands - Good indicator of ecological condition
Not in TSH - But widespread across the UK in base-rich woodlands  - Good indicator of ecological condition
Confined to the East of Engalnd only, very localised. Excluded.
Follows TSH, with the addition of BU where it also found
Folows TSH - although could include in acidic lowland?
Follows TSH, with the addition of BU where it also found
Follows TSH, easy to identify, good indicator of species-rich wet open wooded habitat with periodic disturbance
Indicative of disturbance, not in TSH
Follows TSH
Follows TSH, grouped field and dog together for ease of surveying
Follows TSH
Follows TSH
Follows TSH - A good indicator of ancient / long-established woodlands - Characteristic leaf for ID.

Aggregated as both in alternate and opposite-leaved are good indicators of wet wooded habitat and found in damp areas of base-rich woodland, with alternate-leaved also found in acidic upland. Fairly easy to identify to species level, but perhaps a step too far?
Not in TSH - a good indicator of wet woodland habitat but aggregated with opposite-leaved
In the TSH - a good indicator of wet woodland habitat but aggregated with alternate-leaved
Need to think / consult re: sedges
Not in TSH - Negative indicator - Moderate ecological value, can be competative and reduce diversity
Follows TSH
Follows TSH
Not in TSH - A good indicator of ancient woodland but hybridises with garden varieties and fairly uncommon, and is an introduced species to ireland (according to Kew)

There a multiple speedwells that are challengint o tell apart, with only Wood speedwell an AW specialists. There are 2 speedweels that are encountered that are introduced species and thereore excluded as not being reliable

A good indicator of base-rich ancient woodland, but not native to Ireland. It can be confused with young rhododendron, so it is good to have on the training list so that postive identification is assured.
Not included as ID to species level possible but maybe too challenging
Follows TSH -Easy to ID as a 'strawberry', familiarity to ID between barren and wild
Follows TSH -Easy to ID as a 'strawberry', familiarity to ID between barren and wild
A good indicator of Ancient Woodland, but can be a tricky ID, can be confused with chickweed, only in BL in TSH but widespread across UK in base-rich woodland
Not in TSH, possibly to uncommon in the North and Scotland tobe useful? Could also be confused with garden escapees with which it hybrisises.
Not in TSH, but easy ID, and althougth realtively scarce it is widespread within its range and confined to acidic sites with which it is strongly associated with.

There are several native violets that are woodland specialists. The common found in AU, BU and AL, Early dog, and Sweeet found in BL, and Marsh violet (not in TSH but agood  wet woodland indicator with high ecological value. The leaves are easy to ID, and so as they are mutallay exclusive across the habiatats, the presence of violet in any is a useful indicator.
Follows TSH - Easy ID, stongloy assocaited with base-rich wet woodlands, widespread, tends to be a lowland species.
Follows TSH - A good indicator of ecological condition - Although it is early spring species, it can be diificult to detect later in the season, but easy ID.
In TSH in AL only, but found in upland sites also and is widespread across the UK
Follows TSH - Easy ID, a good indicator of good ecological condition.
Follows TSH - Generally confined to the lowlands
Follows TSH - A good indicator of ancient woodland, does not like acidic or wet soils, mostly southern species but also found across UK.
Follows TSH - Easy ID, can be indicative of disturbance and can sometimes be a liitle dominant, but a good plant for pollinators.
